channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cheney Defends C.I.A. Tactics in Counterattack on Senate Report on Torture
item.description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney mounted a spirited rebuttal to the Senate committee’s torture report, saying there was no comparison between the C.I.A.’s tactics and terrorists’ actions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: On NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Dick Cheney denied that waterboarding and related interrogation tactics were torture.

item.title: American Who Crossed Into North Korea Denounces the U.S.
item.description: The man, who identified himself as Arturo Pierre Martinez and said that he had entered North Korea illegally, offered a lengthy criticism of the United States during a news conference.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Arturo Pierre Martinez, 29, from El Paso, Tex., at a news conference in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Sunday. Mr. Martinez’s mother told CNN that her son had bipolar disorder.

item.title: Israel’s Natural Gas Supply Offers Lifeline for Peace
item.description: A new bonanza of resources could improve the nation’s ties with Egypt, Jordan and even the Palestinian Authority. The linchpin of this diplomatic push: an oil company in Texas.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: The gas rig Tamar, off the Israeli coast. Natural gas is both a geopolitical tool and a target in Israel.

item.title: Abe Appears to Win Landslide Victory in Parliamentary Elections
item.description: Exit polls showed the governing party of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on course to win as many as 306 seats, enough to keep its majority.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe answered questions during a television interview at his party headquarters in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Turkish Police Officers and Media Workers Are Detained in Roundup
item.description: The authorities took at least 24 officers and media workers into custody on Sunday, days after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan signaled a new campaign against supporters of a U.S.-based Muslim cleric.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Climate Deal Would Commit Every Nation to Limiting Emissions
item.description: The agreement reached in Lima, Peru, would be a breakthrough in 20 years of efforts by the United Nations to create a serious global warming accord, but it falls short of what scientists say is needed.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Representatives applauded at the approval of an agreement reached in Lima, Peru, on Sunday to reduce the global rate of greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Peru Plans to Charge Greenpeace Activists for Damage to Nazca Lines
item.description: About a dozen people entered a fragile protected area around the archaeological feature, leaving marks on the rocks.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Republic of Peru, Ministry of Culture
item.media:description: Officials from Peru's Ministry of Culture, wearing special shoes, walk along the trail left by Greenpeace activists.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Militants Killed in Shootout at Saudi Border
item.description: A Yemeni border guard shot and killed three men who were wearing women’s veils as they tried to cross into Saudi Arabia with a male driver on Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Rival Forces Clash Over Eastern Oil Ports
item.description: Forces loyal to Libya’s recognized government on Saturday carried out airstrikes near the eastern oil ports of Ras Lanuf and Es-Sider to stop an advance by a rival militia, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: An Ebola Orphan’s Plea in Africa: ‘Do You Want Me?’
item.description: After her mother died of Ebola, a young girl in Sierra Leone was left an orphan when nobody in her village, even relatives, wanted to take her, though she showed no symptoms of the virus.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sweetie Sweetie, center, with other Ebola orphans at a group home in Sierra Leone. She is seen by neighbors as a potential carrier.

item.title: How to Help Sweetie Sweetie
item.description: The home where Sweetie Sweetie is staying is sponsored by ChildFund International, a private aid agency.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Liberian Court Rejects Petition to Delay Elections Over Ebola
item.description: Liberia’s Supreme Court on Saturday said it would not halt Senate elections scheduled for Tuesday, but the ultimate day of the vote remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: Tens of Thousands Protest in Poland Over Results of Local Elections
item.description: The leader of Poland’s largest opposition party claimed that the results of last month’s municipal elections had been falsified.
item.dc:creator: By JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Robert B. Oakley, Envoy Deft at Tackling Crises, Dies at 83
item.description: Mr. Oakley was best known for negotiating the release of an American pilot held by Somali militiamen in 1993 in what was known as the “Black Hawk Down” crisis.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Patrick De Noirmont

item.title: A Pastor’s Turn Fighting for Ukraine
item.description: Sergei I. Reuta, a Pentecostal minister, picked up a Kalashnikov rifle to volunteer with the Ukrainian Army, where he routinely held court at his post and cooked for his unit.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei I. Reuta, right, and other Ukrainian army soldiers in Pervomaiske, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: News Analysis: Where Tech Giants Protect Privacy
item.description: Regulations on personal data are tougher abroad.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: In Myanmar, Racing to Save a Colonial Past in Decay
item.description: Preservationists are working to salvage badly deteriorating buildings in Yangon’s historic downtown.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Secretariat, once the heart of the government, is closed and needs an estimated $100 million in repairs.

item.title: The New Smoke: China’s E-Cigarette Boom Lacks Oversight for Safety
item.description: Almost all of the world’s e-cigarettes are made without oversight, and experts say flawed or sloppy manufacturing could account for some of the hazards seen in the devices.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: For Jihadists, Denmark Tries Rehabilitation
item.description: A pioneering program treats former fighters not as criminals or potential terrorists, but as wayward youths who deserve a second chance.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Jan Grarup for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oussama el-Saadi, chairman of the Grimhojvej mosque, which critics say breeds radicalism.

item.title: Islamic State Imposes Strict New Order in Mosul, and Deprivation Is a Result
item.description: Six months after the Islamic State seized Iraq’s second-largest city, it has exerted tight control over schools and other aspects of society while doing little to provide services.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: A police station in Mosul. The militants have recruited men for their Islamic Police, giving them guns, salaries and patrol cars.
